PageElement.TextBox:
In this lesson we will provide you with an introduction and some background to the Dangerous Goods Safety Act 2004 (WA) .
 
We will help you to apply your knowledge by asking you questions about a hypothetical situation.
 
Please note that these questions are not scored and that your response is not recorded. You can use the feedback provided to consolidate what you have learned in this lesson.
 
Click on the Quick Facts menu button above to view a summary of the lesson.
 
Click the ► button below to continue, or select a topic from the Table of Contents list.

PageElement.TOC:
Table of Contents
  • Learning objectives
  • Case Study
  • What are dangerous goods?
  • Dangerous goods classification

  • Definitions

PageElement.TextBox:
In this lesson you will learn:
 
  • the background to the Act
 
  • what regulations are relevant to your organisation
 
  • the objectives of the Act
 
  • what matters are covered in the Act
 
  • who administers the Act
 
  • the definition of dangerous goods.
 
You should complete the lesson in about 20 minutes.
 
To get started, please click on the ► button below.

Botany Bay v Pryor [2009]
This case concerned a dispute over the requisite quantity of goods that would be deemed "dangerous" if held at a workplace. A Botany Bay Council employee was injured when siphoning liquid chlorine from a tank to container. As a result, the Council was convicted of a contravention of s 9(1) of the Dangerous Goods Act 1975 (NSW) (Act).
Both parties conceded that if over 1000 litres of liquid chlorine were kept on the premises, the Council would have been in breach of its obligations under the Act. However, in the view of the NSW Industrial Relations Commission, there was not sufficient evidence to sustain a finding that on the day of the offence, there was a quantity in excess of 1000 litres of liquid chlorine kept on the premises. As such, no offence had been committed under the Act.

Dangerous goods are goods that have the potential to cause immediate harm to people, property and the environment. This is due to the possibility of a fire, explosion, or release of toxic, flammable or corrosive materials during a storage or handling incident.
 
Hazardous substances are those that, following exposure, can have an adverse effect on health. Examples of hazardous substances include poisons, substances that cause burns or skin and eye irritation, and substances that may cause cancer. Many hazardous substances are also classified as dangerous goods.
 
The focus of the definition of dangerous goods is on the acute effect of these substances. They generally have the following properties:
 
  • an ability to cause corrosion of skin and other materials
  • capacity to harm the environment
  • an ability to cause or accelerate combustion
  • acute toxic effects
  • temperature or pressure hazards
  • ability to react with other materials adversely
  • potential to cause asphyxiation by displacement of oxygen

Based on their hazardous properties there are nine classes of dangerous goods, some of which are further divided into divisions.
The Western Australian dangerous goods safety legislation covers nine classes of dangerous goods, based on their hazardous properties, some of which are further divided into divisions:
 
  • Class 1 (explosives)
  • Class 2 (gases)
  • Class 3 (flammable liquids)
  • Class 4 (flammable solids, substances liable to spontaneous combustion, substances that in contact with water emit flammable gases)
  • Class 5 (oxidising substances, organic peroxides)
  • Division 6.1 (toxic substances)
  • Class 8 (corrosive substances)
  • Class 9 (miscellaneous dangerous goods and articles)
 
Note that there are also:
 
  • Goods too dangerous to be transported
  • C1 combustible liquids (combustible liquid with flashpoint between 60.5 and 150°C)
 
Notable omissions from the list are:
 
  • Division 6.2 (infectious substances); and
  • Class 7 (radioactive substances).

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here to read more
    The Government of Western Australia Department of Mines and Petroleum has released a Dangerous Goods Safety Information Sheet. It sets out which goods are dangerous and which are hazardous.
     
    Click here to see more.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
On 1 March 2008, the Dangerous Goods Safety Act 2004 (WA) and its associated regulations came into effect.
 
The Act was passed four years earlier in 2004 but it did not come into force until seven supporting regulations were drafted and approved. These regulations address issues relating to major hazard facilities, storage and handling of non-explosives and security risk substances. You can find more information about the seven regulations and what they aim to do in the section below.
 
The Act changed the way in which dangerous goods and major hazard facilities are regulated in Western Australia. By requiring industry to take reasonable and practicable measures to manage the risk involved with dangerous goods, the Act seeks to minimise risks to people, property and the environment.
 
It aims to reduce the focus on governmental regulation as a way of managing risks and instead shifts the responsibility to industry itself.
 
The Act and its associated regulations replaced the Explosives and Dangerous Goods Act 1961 (WA) and Dangerous Goods (Transport) Act 1998 (WA).

PageElement.TextBox:
Which regulations are most relevant to your organisation?
 
The three supporting regulations to the Act which are most relevant are the:
 
  1. Dangerous Goods Safety (Storage and Handling of Non-explosives) Regulations 2007
 
  1. Dangerous Goods Safety (Road and Rail Transport of Non-explosives) Regulations 2007
 
  1. Dangerous Goods Safety (Explosives) Regulations 2007.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for more information about how the Act relates to other laws
    Relationship with other laws
     
    1. This Act does not apply to a pipeline carrying dangerous goods, to which the Gas Standards Act 1972, Petroleum Pipelines Act 1969 or Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1982 applies.
     
    1. If another written law applies to or in respect of dangerous goods, that law applies in addition to this Act, unless subsection (3) or (4) applies or this Act expressly provides otherwise.
     
    1. If a provision of this Act conflicts or is inconsistent with a provision of another written law that applies to or in relation to dangerous goods, the provision of this Act prevails, unless subsection (4) applies.
     
    1. If a provision of this Act conflicts or is inconsistent with a provision of another written law that applies to or in relation to dangerous goods of a category that is prescribed for the purposes of this subsection by regulations made under this Act, the provision of the other written law prevails.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
The Act updates the legislation regulating the way that dangerous goods must be stored, handled and transported in Western Australia. It also introduces stricter licensing requirements for companies that handle dangerous goods.
 
The Act is designed to shift the responsibility for the management of dangerous goods from government to private industry. It adopts a risk-management approach to dangerous goods and incorporates performance-based standards and codes of practice.
 
The Act places a general duty on companies to minimise risks associated with dangerous goods that may affect people, property and the environment. It requires industry participants to take all reasonably practicable measures to manage these risks.
 
In relation  to dangerous goods, risk means the probability of:
 
  1. the goods causing the death of, unreasonable injury to, or unreasonable harm to the health of, one or more individuals
 
  1. the goods causing unreasonable damage or harm to property or the environment

There are a great number of matters that are covered by the Act. These include:
 
  • General duties as to dangerous goods
 
  • Regulations and codes of practice
 
  • Exemptions
 
  • Administration
 
  • Investigation and enforcement
 
  • Legal proceedings
 
  • Miscellaneous issues

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here to learn about additional requirements in Western Australia
    In Western Australia there are a few additional requirements. For example, all sulphur is a dangerous good for storage and handling, irrespective of form (such as lump sulphur).
     
    C1 combustible liquids (such as diesel fuel) are classified as dangerous goods for storage purposes, but not for road and rail transport.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
The Resources Safety Division within the Western Australian Department of Mines and Petroleum (the Department) administers the:
 
  • Dangerous Goods Safety Act 2004 (WA)
 
  • Dangerous Goods Safety Regulations 2007 (WA) supporting the Act.
 
The Department is responsible for issuing licences, inspecting storage sites, facilities and vehicles used for transporting dangerous goods, and responding to incidents and complaints.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here to learn about the regulation of hazardous substances
    Hazardous substances used at mining operations in Western Australia are regulated under the Mines Safety and Inspection Regulations 1995, which are administered by Resources Safety.
    Hazardous substances at non-mining workplaces are regulated under the Occupational Safety and Health Act 1984 and attendant regulations, which are administered by the WorkSafe Division of the Department of Commerce.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
What are dangerous goods?
 
Dangerous goods are special category of hazardous substances and articles that have the potential to cause immediate harm to people, property and the environment.
 
The focus of the definition of dangerous is on the acute effect of these substances.
 
Hazardous substances are those that, following exposure, can have an adverse effect on health.
 
Examples of hazardous substances include poisons, substances that cause burns or skin and eye irritation, and substances that may cause cancer.
 
Hazardous substances used at mining operations in Western Australia are regulated under the Mines Safety and Inspection Regulations 1995, which are administered by Resources Safety.
Hazardous substances at non-mining workplaces are regulated under the Occupational Safety and Health Act 1984 and attendant regulations, which are administered by the WorkSafe Division of the Department of Commerce.
Many hazardous substances are also classified as dangerous goods.

Congratulations!
 
You have completed your lesson.
